newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian police ban demonstrations to mark hangings.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian police ban demonstrations to mark hangings.

text.p: Police in the oil-producing state of Rivers in southeastern Nigeria have banned demonstrations to mark the first anniversary on Sunday of the hanging of rights activist and author Ken Saro-Wiwa, newspapers said on Tuesday.

The Movement for the Survival of Ogoni Peoples (MOSOP), of which Saro-Wiwa was national president when he and eight MOSOP activists were hanged, said separately there would be no mass rallies in order to avoid a clash with security forces.
"The remembrance will be observed quietly...there is absolutely no cause for celebration or crowded observation in the face of glaring threats," a MOSOP statement said.
Rivers state police commissioner Muktar Alkali told a news conference in the state capital Port Harcourt he had received information of plans to disturb the peace.

"The police command hereby warns that it will not hesitate to deal ruthlessly with anyone caught organising or participating in such illegal acts," he was quoted by the independent Guardian newspaper as saying.
Ogoniland is troubled by attempts to establish self-determination for the 500,000-strong community which MOSOP championed under Saro-Wiwa's leadership.
Nigeria caused international outrage last November 10 when Saro-Wiwa and eight other MOSOP activists were hanged for the murder of four Ogoni chiefs.
The activists had been tried under a military decree condemned worldwide as unfair. Nigeria was suspended from the Commonwealth and various sanctions imposed on it by mainly Western nations.
In the run-up to the anniversary of the hangings, MOSOP alleged there had been a renewed crackdown on the Ogoni people by security forces. The charge was denied by the authorities.
